feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Luis clearly articulated a small number of high-impact initiatives that mattered deeply to the client. He demonstrated strong judgment in prioritizing GMP compliance, FDA inspection readiness, and SOP modernization, and clearly explained why these efforts were critical to Takeda’s risk profile and long-term operations. The narrative was outcome-driven, showed ownership end-to-end, and made it clear what changed for the client as a result of the work.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Luis delivered exceptional examples of value beyond contract scope. He translated operational improvements into tangible financial, sustainability, and risk-reduction outcomes, including meaningful cost avoidance, waste reduction, and regulatory confidence. The work demonstrated intentional decision-making, proactive partnership, and a clear understanding of how to align SBM’s efforts with Takeda’s strategic priorities.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Cost savings were clearly articulated, quantified, and tied to repeatable process improvements rather than one-time actions. Luis showed strong ownership of execution, from SOP redesign through testing, implementation, and hypercare. The savings were framed in a way that demonstrated long-term sustainability and strong financial stewardship, reinforcing SBM’s role as a trusted operational partn
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Luis demonstrated meaningful innovation within a highly regulated environment, which is notably difficult to do well. His ability to influence SOP changes after a decade, introduce reusable materials, and advance sustainability programs reflects mature leadership, credibility with the client, and continuous improvement thinking. Innovation was practical, scalable, and client-centric.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Luis acknowledged the increased complexity and risk associated with higher compliance requirements and increased documentation volume, and clearly owned the operational response. He demonstrated accountability by explaining how risk was actively managed rather than avoided. This section would be further strengthened by briefly highlighting one or two lessons learned that could be applied to other GMP accounts.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Luis presented a clear forward-looking strategy tied to electronic logbooks, continued sustainability leadership, and deeper operational partnership. The path forward felt intentional and aligned with Takeda’s trajectory. This section could be elevated by explicitly calling out how SBM will scale or replicate these wins across other regulated accounts.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Luis demonstrated strong role maturity through the way he spoke about partnership, accountability, and long-term impact. While personal development goals were not explicitly outlined, his ownership of complex, high-risk initiatives signals readiness for increased scope. Articulating personal growth objectives would further strengthen future reviews.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:
The strongest, most structured presentations across the group (so far). His visuals were clear, his narrative was disciplined, and his delivery balanced confidence with credibility. He communicated complex regulatory and operational topics in a way that was accessible, compelling, and executive-ready.

Luis delivered an exceptional year-end review that exemplifies what strong account leadership looks like in a regulated, high-stakes environment. He demonstrated clear ownership, strategic thinking, and the ability to translate complex work into meaningful client outcomes. This was a best-in-class performance and a strong benchmark for GMP and enterprise accounts moving forward.

feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills:
Scott has made this hard landing look easy for those on the outside or have not been apart of this from the beginning. Sanofi was not an easy account, it was bid very aggressively from a financial standpoint. On top of an extremely complex environment with GMP and new program with Slurry. From the start, Scott owned it. He transitioned it seamlessly and have managed it exceptionally well.

What really stood out to me is that it didn’t suck the life out of the SLT team and that says a lot. That doesn’t happen often. You consistently provided updates the good, the bad, and the ugly and regardless of the challenge, you came with a solution. You didn’t just bring problems up; you solved them.

Most importantly, you’re a trusted advisor for both SBM and the client. While all ADs are empowered, in this case it genuinely showed. as said in the presentation they have been very reluctant to make a change.

Everything you have done for the last 12 months has positioned you and SBM very well for the growth. Excited to see those results in 2026!

accountDirectors.account: Micron Tech, Mp Mask Technology Center

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Clearly frames the most important 2025 initiatives, why they mattered, and what changed for the client as a result; demonstrates strong judgment, prioritization, and impact awareness. From sustainability, to additional cleaning you create client impact.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: San Jose was a challenge that you were able to overcome! Clearly articulates value delivered regarding the additional resources to support the work at no cost to the customer. James' question helped flush out how we quantified the value increased quality.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Sid you clearly explained the way you thought about ways to save the client money. You thought about the best way to save long term ie : Paper products. I also love the sustainability twist on using all of the toilet paper etc it is a best practice. Many people do not think about savings based on supplies or reduction to sub contracted labor. Way to increase your scope and save the customer a creative win!
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: I really appreciated that you didnt look only at autonomous equipment, the whiz or other basic equipment. I liked that you used product, this is a best practice! Increasing productivity!!! Thats a win we need to share this Urine Digester with all of Operations!  A lot of equipment that improved our service delivery and added visible value to the customer.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Thank you for being fully transparent about challenges, clearly owns gaps, and outlines specific corrective actions with timelines. I appreciate you owning it, and more importantly closing the gaps. You might be one of he few who actually put in their do different.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: You have had a great presentation so far I look forward to more dates and depth around what you will implement when? I want a true timeline of implementation, testing whatever you have to do. Be ahead of the customer that is very important you are on the right track with that. I like that you are focused on growth and retention.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Add dates to your goals so when you meet with leadership you can share where you are to the dates you set for yourself.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: You communication of your account story is clear and confident. I appreciated hearing all about your plans, I agree we have to be aggressive we have to have a win strategy. I need you to partner with Nick V and Nicole on how to push our way into more. You do a great job finding opportunities. When you close Singapore I want to celebrate in a big way!

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: I think there's an opportunity to tie more of our initiatives to our customer's goals in order to better define impact. One public example, waste reduction. Micron is targeting 95% diversion from landfill. If our sustainability initiative is to use cores of paper towels, etc. toward reuse but ultimately they still end up in the landfill, our initiative may be slightly misaligned with Micron's overall goal. Maybe we target dual roll dispensers from GP that automatically dispense a second roll towel when the first roll depletes, encouraging full utilization of that stub roll. Tork Peakserve is another potential option. I think you gave some compelling examples of initiatives (plate scraping, etc) that have real impact on the client's goals. Just want to encourage more communication around what the client's specific goals are, even searching publicly available information, and crafting our initiatives and messaging around how we can impact them.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Provided strong examples of value creation with diretional financial framing. I LOVED that you called out window cleaning cost savings leading to enhanced service performance at the SJC site. We tend to forget about "savings" like this that don't result in YOY impact, but the fact that funds were able to be pivoted into other customer priorities with SBM is exactly the kind of cost savings we want to drive. Savings on urinal mats and other initiatives could be quanitifed, tightened. But each was a compelling example.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Regarding value-added work, I'm not sure there was a quantified amount that we delivered to the client in SJC, which makes me wonder if the client understands the value of our reinvestment into that site. It's 100% OK to deliver a project at no charge or at cost, better if the client knows they're getting something for free, and best for the client to know (and be reminded of) the estimated values of of the work we've done for them. Again, thought you had strong examples here, I just wonder if we could tighten up some of the quantified impact.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: Mentioned this on the call, but I love that you are leaning into areas where the company has limited playbook for you to go off of (construction cleaning, MAC work, event support, & more). You're helping write the playbook, and I think that's impressive and commendable.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: We trust your assessment that the gaps in SJC were largely due to a demanding client. This may have glazed over some of the real misses down there, and opportunities for improvement. The end result is that you managed the account and led the team to right wrongs and improe our service. Just think there may have been more room for partial ownership of challenges down there, and that honestly they would have done nothing but strengthen your already strong credibility on the call.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Love the tenacity on Micron Singapore. Second the feedback of others regarding intermediate steps, or the bite-size chunks you'll be taking along the way. I think others were concerned about time-bound goals, I'd encourage more thinking around what needs to happen, in sequence, for your big vision to take effect, and road-mapping that for SLT.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Feedback previously given regarding time-bound goals, but I think you had a strong vision for where the account can and will be in 2027 and I very much look forward to seeing and helping you achieve it.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: Discussion was led with confidence and authority, with a well-constructed story of achievements on the account. Your presentation style is engaging and easy to interact with.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: You key projects also highlighted your challenges and changes. I appreciate how you didnt just discuss the activity, but the results from changes we made.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives:
Strong overview of the reviewed projects, with clear articulation of both client impact and the SBM solutions delivered. Regarding scope alignment, I would have appreciated additional detail on how the misalignment originated and whether any corrective steps were taken before end user concerns surfaced and the final resolution was reached. It would also be helpful to understand how our partnership and working relationship with JLL influenced the process and outcome.

Overall, you demonstrated a solid partnership mindset and the ability to pivot effectively to support initiatives that matter to both our client and the end users.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance:
Regarding the value add, I believe there was a missed opportunity to highlight the leadership impact created by having two dedicated leaders supporting IBM. With SBM investing in the partnership through both you and Lou, it would have been helpful to understand how this has strengthened relationships with both onsite and offsite leadership teams. We know this investment has created tangible benefits, and further elaboration would have reinforced that point.

On cost avoidance and savings, you delivered a clear and effective communication of the financial impacts, successfully demonstrating our value as a strategic partner.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: The cost‑savings presented were impactful, though largely one‑time initiatives. Identifying more sustainable, long‑term savings may be challenging due to current contractual limitations and wage related constraints. It would have been helpful to see additional perspective on the ongoing challenges of sustaining cost savings efforts; however, the one‑time savings delivered still provide meaningful value to our partner.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement:
Even while our IFM partners were undergoing their RFP process, you continued to present technology proposals and solutions that demonstrated SBM’s commitment to a long‑term partnership. You noted your engagement with the HSSE partner at JLL and the review of our Good Catch program as an added benefit. Additional clarity on the specific advantages this provided JLL and the resulting impact on our relationship, would have strengthened the narrative.

The internal ATB tracker is a solid enhancement and represents a valuable new tool for internal operations.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Your dialogue with Nick V. provided a strong opportunity to further demonstrate your depth of knowledge and experience on the account. I also appreciate your openness to learning and your willingness to incorporate additional perspectives, such as bringing Melissa into the conversation to help strengthen opportunities and solutions.
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Focusing on a successful RFP and the upcoming Austin transition represents the most clearly defined and impactful priorities we can have at this stage. It’s encouraging to hear the proactive steps being taken to ensure success, as well as your clear understanding of the timelines involved. Incorporating potential innovations into the Austin site for future consideration also demonstrates forward thinking beyond the transition itself and highlights opportunities for added value.
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: I appreciate the personal accountability you demonstrate in recognizing what you don’t yet know whether due to tenure or coming from outside the industry. Strong self‑awareness is essential for growth and development. You clearly outlined your goals with timelines and desired outcomes, all of which will positively impact you, our customers, and the advancement of your team.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: I’ll tie this back to both your dialogue with Nick V. and your exchange with Valarie. Your ability to respond confidently and clearly to unrehearsed, unscripted questions demonstrates strong executive presence. With Valarie’s line of questioning, I would have liked to hear a more “bottom line up front” approach, especially since you have the knowledge and insight to address her budget questions with even greater clarity.You did an excellent job presenting a cohesive, well‑structured story each slide building logically on the last and tying the full narrative together. Well done.

feedback.Key Projects & Initiatives: Finding it really hard to hear a benefit project strategy that the AD came up with. The main benefit communicated was that we had a successful transition. While this is critical clients expect this. While you were able to describe a few initiatives, you focused more on execution than client outcomes or strategic impact. We have made reductions in cost by 16%, but have not implemented scope changes or HC reductions. You stated we will be ready to execute all reductions the minute we have a renewal - HC reductions coming based on scope changes, noted: JLL has been informed. The opportunity is in 2026 to create a strategic plan to show Wells SBM is different from our competitors.
feedback.Value Adds & Cost Avoidance: Adding service locations benefits SBM even if they are sites we did not want to add. I can see the value in using us, but that as a value add doesn't save the customer money. Equipment was a good one, and Canteen support we are paid for this activity and in order to add this we have to be able to quantify the amount we save.
feedback.Cost Savings Delivered: Clearly explains how cost savings were created, quantified, and sustained. We have a gap in our ability to solve it internally. We should be able to deliver cost savings and reduce and still delight the customer from a quality perspective.
feedback.Innovation & Continuous Improvement: The client didnt necessarily see the value of the QR code / pilot. They felt like it was an SBM value add to us to do our job. We missed an opportunity to communicate with the customer how service validation works to drive behavior. Opportunity to - Quantify an increase in audit scores as well. Your thoughts are this doesnt work where the audit scores are acceptable. You are using it to prove frequency, but we can measure this. (No using the photo upload /so we arent using the latest technology). Retail project identified as an innovation - how could we aggressively go after Merchants in 2025 this should've been a goal. This project was implemented but not sustained.
feedback.Issues, Challenges & Accountability: Identifies challenges and discusses improvement actions with reasonable clarity. We have a contractual change from scoring criteria. JLL transferred from CBRE in November 1st (4) months in with misalignment we need to reset baselines, and scoring criteria. I would like to understand the timeline of when this will be completed by. Upon award of sites meeting to be set realign. (TBD)
feedback.2026 Forward Strategy & Vision: Shares general goals or aspirations without clear execution detail. Reiterating the need for dates to hold yourself and your team accountable to achieving your plans and I would like to see the strategy more flushed out around the accounts opportunities. Will all locations be handled the same? What if any nuances by location?
feedback.Personal Goals & Role Maturity: Shares general development intentions without clear measures or ownership. Again timelines are important and the how you will achieve the goals is important. Expanding to new locations is a great idea, how will you do that? What next steps will you take to take over sites that arent in the RFP? What relationships do you need that you dont have today? Overall I need more details around your goals. I recommend using the SMART method to ensure they are specific, measurable, achievable, relevant and time bound. Your goals will be uploaded into Workday, this is very important for monthly / quarterly and annual touch base.
feedback.Executive Presence & Presentation Skills: Communicates clearly with logical flow; delivers a cohesive account story with minor gaps in strategy and timelines. You are able to really tell your story well as it pertains to people, and the account. I challenge you to really set the account up with mapping out the goals, identifying gaps, issues, and objections (both internal and external)

Key Projects & Initiatives.definition: Evaluates ability to articulate meaningful work and outcomes

criteria.5: Clearly frames the most important 2025 initiatives, why they mattered, and what changed for the client as a result; demonstrates strong judgment, prioritization, and impact awareness
criteria.4: Presents a clear narrative of key initiatives and outcomes, with minor gaps in impact clarity or measurement
criteria.3: Accurately describes initiatives but focuses more on execution than client outcomes or strategic impact
criteria.2: Mentions projects but lacks ownership, prioritization, or clarity on why they mattered
criteria.1: Unable to clearly articulate major initiatives or their relevance

Value Adds & Cost Avoidance.definition: Evaluates ability to demonstrate value beyond contract scope

criteria.5: Clearly articulates value delivered beyond contract scope and translates it into estimated financial, operational, or risk-based impact
criteria.4: Provides strong examples of value creation with partial or directional financial framing
criteria.3: Describes value adds but does not translate them into financial or business impact
criteria.2: Examples are vague or lack clarity on value delivered

Cost Savings Delivered.definition: Evaluates financial stewardship and operational efficiency

criteria.5: Clearly explains how cost savings were created, quantified, and sustained; demonstrates strong financial stewardship
criteria.4: Identifies cost savings with reasonable clarity and some indication of sustainability
criteria.3: Mentions cost savings but with limited explanation or primarily one-time impact
criteria.2: Savings referenced without clear understanding, ownership, or credibility

Innovation & Continuous Improvement.definition: Evaluates leadership in evolving service delivery

criteria.5: Demonstrates intentional innovation or meaningful pivots, with clear outcomes and lessons learned
criteria.4: Introduced improvements or adaptations that positively impacted the account
criteria.3: Participated in improvement efforts but with limited leadership or ownership
criteria.2: Discusses ideas or concepts without execution or demonstrated impact
criteria.1: No evidence of innovation or continuous improvement

Issues, Challenges & Accountability.definition: Evaluates self-awareness, ownership, and executive leadership

criteria.5: Fully transparent about challenges, clearly owns gaps, and outlines specific corrective actions with timelines
criteria.4: Identifies challenges and discusses improvement actions with reasonable clarity
criteria.3: Acknowledges issues but provides limited reflection, ownership, or follow-through
criteria.2: Defensive, vague, or minimizes challenges without accountability
criteria.1: Avoids or fails to address challenges altogether

2026 Forward Strategy & Vision.definition: Evaluates strategic thinking and future readiness

Benjamin Ehrenberg.title: Quantifying Value-Adds Methodology
Benjamin Ehrenberg.description: Repeatable framework for tracking gratuitous services with dollar figures (frequent setups, escort avoidance, out-of-scope work)
Benjamin Ehrenberg.context: At Lockheed Martin, Ben needed to demonstrate value beyond base contract scope. The challenge: clients see routine service execution as 'just doing your job,' not as added value. Ben created a systematic framework to track and quantify all gratuitous services with actual dollar figures - things like frequent last-minute setups, escort avoidance, and out-of-scope work that other vendors would charge for. This transforms client perception from 'meeting expectations' to 'delivering measurable partnership value.' Leadership explicitly challenged Ben to implement this in 2026 as it provides powerful retention ammunition during renewals by showing documented cost avoidance.
Benjamin Ehrenberg.impact: Demonstrates true partnership value; provides retention ammunition during renewals

Mark Schlerf.title: Gap Analysis as Strategic Opportunity Framework
Mark Schlerf.description: Turn CBRE Lam Research gap analysis (potential minefield showing contract vs. actual performance) into strategic investment opportunities by showing 'what is different by location and what the opportunities are' for client to fund improvements
Mark Schlerf.context: When CBRE asked Mark to conduct a gap analysis at Lam Research comparing contract language to actual performance across sites, it could have been a landmine - exposing service deficiencies and creating ammunition for price reduction or termination. Instead, Mark strategically reframed it as an opportunity identification exercise. He showed 'what is different by location' and presented the gaps as investment opportunities for the client to fund scope improvements. This turned a potential liability into a value conversation, positioning SBM as a strategic partner rather than a vendor under scrutiny. Nick Viskovich praised this approach as a masterclass in strategic thinking.
Mark Schlerf.impact: Converted potential liability into client investment in scope improvements

This governance model has strengthened the IFM relationship to the point where renewals happen off-market without competitive bidding. Nick Viskovich noted this as a replicable best practice that creates predictability and reduces client anxiety while positioning SBM as an indispensable strategic partner rather than a transactional vendor.

Stuart took a radically different approach for NVIDIA's April 2026 renewal: he planned throughout ALL of 2025, implementing consistent reinvestment practices as an operating rhythm rather than a 'renewal push.' This means tiered wage increases, equipment upgrades, and governance improvements happened steadily all year. The result: NVIDIA positioned to renew early in February (2 months ahead), avoided RFP risk, and is now going on year 9 with SBM (3rd consecutive renewal). Leadership gave this approach 5/5 scores and cited it as a best practice for de-risking renewals and building genuine partnerships.

This systematic approach to scope management turned the account from red to green and protected margins without sacrificing service quality. Peggy Shum.title: Vacation Coverage Bench Strategy ($21/hr vs $31/hr + No Benefits)
Peggy Shum.description: Built reliable 6-person bench at $21/hr (vs $31/hr regular union rate + benefits) to eliminate OT and ATB time for vacation coverage; solved summer 2025 crisis
Peggy Shum.context: Prior to bench, vacation coverage used ATB time and overtime at $31/hr fully-burdened rate plus health benefits. Summer 2025 was 'rough' - high vacation season, limited bench, undocumented approvals, no centralized tracking. Staff covered 2-3 positions simultaneously, creating visible gaps and evening catch-up churn. Peggy centralized vacation tracking/approval rules and built 6-person VR bench at $21/hr sustained lower rate. Now maps out vacations in advance. Result: eliminated OT for coverage, more stable operations, reliable coverage, consistency for staff. Also uses VRs for ATB projects to retain more margin vs regular employees on OT. Example: Interior window cleaning ($40-50K project) increased margin to 50% by using VRs instead of dedicating half of foreman's time (which was loss of oversight).
Peggy Shum.impact: Eliminated vacation OT; $10/hr wage savings + no benefits; 50% margin on window cleaning; stable coverage
Peggy Shum.leadership_endorsement: Demonstrated cost containment and operational stability in constrained environment

Peggy Shum.title: Institutional Knowledge Repository (Shared Folder)
Peggy Shum.description: Created shared folder repository for procedures, processes, and site knowledge to ensure 'knowledge continues living beyond tenure of any manager' and isn't lost with turnover
Peggy Shum.context: Deutsche Bank had management turnover (removed underperforming site manager, Carlos covered intermittent FMLA, Chad Boulton coverage for months, Peggy came on Q2). Peggy Shum.title: Audit Recalibration for Honest Baseline (Scores 4.5 → 4.0 Standard)
Peggy Shum.description: Recalibrated audit scoring from inflated baseline (4.5 with dust/crumbs in photos) to honest reality (4.0 = meets expectations, 5.0 = rare excellence), creating trustworthy system and alignment with CSAT
Peggy Shum.context: In early 2025, site manager was scoring 4.5 while narratives/photos showed dust, crumbs, 'workstations need dusting' - disconnect between scores and reality. This prevented focus on real issues and created confusion: passing audits but failing CSAT. Valarie: 'I knew immediately we had a misalignment.' Peggy worked with CBRE to recalibrate scoring guidelines - 4.0 became baseline (meets expectations), 5.0 became rarity. Initially created 'steep drop' in scores, but it wasn't real decline - it was alignment with reality. Graph showed July as inflection point where recalibration, new management, and other fixes converged to begin recovery. Result: 'System became more trustworthy... protected integrity of our system altogether.' This enabled honest conversations with CBRE about resource needs and positioned for extension grounded in value, not labor cuts.
Peggy Shum.impact: Restored audit integrity; created reliable data for decisions; aligned expectations; enabled honest client conversations
Peggy Shum.leadership_endorsement: Valarie: 'More honest and transparent. Not only do you gain trust, we can rely on the information. I was so confused why we were passing audits but failing CSAT.'

Peggy Shum.context: NYC has different pay rules for shift differentials. 'Regularly monitoring these things... helps us save $500/month per employee.' This is operational hygiene and 'low hanging fruit,' but in upside-down account, 'everything helps.' Demonstrates attention to detail in constrained financial environment where every dollar matters. Part of broader cost containment discipline: 'Turning every cushion... seeking cost containment wherever we can.'
Peggy Shum.impact: ~$500/month savings per affected employee; demonstrates financial discipline in constrained environment
Peggy Shum.replicability: Very High (NYC-specific, but principle applies to any pay rule nuances)
Peggy Shum.leadership_endorsement: Part of comprehensive cost containment in challenging financial environment

Giselle Langelier.title: Educating Client on Contract Language to Limit Credits/Scope Creep

Giselle Langelier.context: Medtronic contract has rate card with positions/hours and clause allowing credit requests for hours not worked. As long as SBM hits 90% of planned hours, client doesn't invoke clause. Small sites (like Irvine bell) notice absences and request credits incorrectly. Example: client asked for 25% credit for 1 of 4 people missing. Giselle educated: 'It doesn't work that way - it's by position (different hourly rates), and you have to account for OT from others covering the gap.' Supervisor position = $30/hr fully burdened, cleaner = $22/hr. Credit calculated by missing position rate minus OT from coverage. Giselle navigated this by: (1) maintaining transparency with hours reports, (2) educating clients on contract language, (3) staying above 90% threshold, and (4) leveraging strong relationships at most sites so clients don't invoke clause. This prevents margin erosion from improper credit requests while maintaining service quality.

This approach allows us to provide adequate coverage, creating more efficient and optimized staffing model, allowing us to hit saving targets without major erosion of service quality.' Results: 'Drove about 9% save across all existing work... monthly decrease of almost 70K per month in terms of savings. With additional site we brought on, we were about 50K per month in terms of revenue to the good.' Quality validation: 'Knock on wood, we've actually seen slight uptick in our overall performance when looking at our quality metrics in Q4 versus Q3.' Mike: 'I anticipate this to be the new norm at some point.' Marvin: 'Mike did real good job to work with union to get their agreement on implementing something like this.'
Michael Barry.impact: 9% savings across existing work ($70K/month); $50K/month additional revenue; quality metrics improved; union buy-in achieved; scalable model
Michael Barry.leadership_endorsement: Mike anticipates 'this to be the new norm'; Marvin praised union negotiation approach

Dustin Smith.title: Office Transition: 55 Sites from Transitional to Sustaining State in 5 Months
Dustin Smith.description: Transitioned 55-site Amazon JLL office portfolio from August 2025 go-live to sustaining operations; integrated incumbent and external hire leaders; established operational stability across 24/7 office environments
Dustin Smith.context: Dustin joined mid-year 2025, went live August 2025 with 55 different office sites under Amazon JLL contract. Challenge: 'We had a lot of different new leaders coming in from either the incumbent or external hires.' This involved: (1) One-on-one meetings with each site leader across entire portfolio to align on scope expectations and outcomes (started September 2025), (2) Scope alignment from frequency-based to outcome-based contract - 'Led to a lot of back and forth on what's in and out of scope... old work orders... team from incumbent was used to billing that,' (3) Shift and task alignment with Amazon 24/7 office schedules - 'They said for years they had been trying to understand Amazon shift schedule. It was our site leadership team that led those discussions,' (4) Management process enhancement - 'We took on a lot of incumbent managers, external hires, nobody with a lot of SBM stink on them... really doing deep dive training and making sure we're bringing our site managers up to SBM standard.' Result: Late December through January saw 'tremendous uptick' in ForSight quality/quantity of audits. Valarie: 'You do really good job typically controlling the room, controlling your customer and you come very well prepared with what you're going to say. You're well spoken. You remain calm.'
Dustin Smith.impact: 55 sites stabilized in 5 months; scope clarity achieved; Amazon shift schedules mapped; site managers elevated to SBM standard; ForSight audit quality increased

Keith Deuber.title: Operationally Focused Leadership Team - Amazon SMEs

Keith Deuber.context: Strategic insight: 'This may be one of the only accounts where truly to the core, winning in Amazon is proving operations and your operational effectiveness.' Team building: 'Throughout the year, obviously Dustin coming on put everything in the hyperdrive. But throughout the year, bringing in Bill Darlington on the East Coast, five years in Amazon, operations through and through. Sam on the West Coast operation through and through, as well as Kathy Telford, who I brought in as MIT, spent eight years on the Amazon accounts. Really a true SME in the space as well as an SME in the categories that we want to break into a bit more, the MX LS, AM ZL and such like that.' Impact on perception: 'I really think this assisted, if not was a key driver in changing the perception of SBM and Amazon's eyes. We've went from having an account team to having a true operations team.' Site-level impact: 'This really successfully assisted in strengthening our site level management as well. These are operators. These are not guys that are going there and just, hey, you got to do this, got to do that, got to do this, they're going there and they're strengthening our on site management, they're mentoring them, they're showing them what to do, leading by example.' Result: 'The outcome of that is, I mean as we can see through peak through the beginning of this year, we're hitting the highest scores ever. I attest that to truly changing our leadership from strictly an account-based to strong operators, which again this account to grow is truly operational success equals growth.'
Keith Deuber.impact: Highest scores ever; perception transformed; site management strengthened; mentoring vs directing; operations = growth equation proven
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Valarie/Nicole: 'Keith, you come really strongly with the operational support. I feel almost every time you talk like if you said it, then it's facts. Like if you said that's the equipment problem, then that's what it is.'

Keith Deuber.title: Relationship Campaign - Operations Team Focus Over Category Team
Keith Deuber.description: Shifted relationship strategy from Amazon category team (who assign initial work) to operations teams (SPMs, RPMs, POLs) who influence site retention, loss, and RFP outcomes; established constant communication
Keith Deuber.context: Strategic shift: 'First and foremost, we were focusing on the wrong group per se. We were focusing on the category team. That category team is what assigns the work initially. But what we didn't have in focus was the operations teams. The operations teams, even though they do not single-handedly assign the work, they do have heavy influence throughout the year of losing sites, winning sites as well as coming up in the 2027 or 2026 RFP.' Target roles: 'We started to meet with the SPMs, the RPMs, as well as the POLs or the procurement operation leaders, and those three roles are really what determines success at a site. A POR can come in, they can stamp of approval or they can put you on a PIP.' Implementation: 'Throughout the year, beginning of the year and then Dustin obviously came on midway through the year and it kind of went into hyperdrive.' Result: 'We shifted our focus throughout 2025 to focus on the procurement operations and getting in front of them, having constant communication and really changing the perspective of Amazon about SBM starting with that group because they have the most I would say influence when it comes to category.'
Keith Deuber.impact: Relationships shifted to operations influencers; constant communication established; Amazon perception of SBM changed; positioned for 2026/2027 RFP success
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Strategic relationship targeting vs transactional category team focus

Keith Deuber.title: Strategic Operations Governance - Daily 15-Min Touchbases During Peak
Keith Deuber.description: Implemented Teams regional chats for real-time communication; established 15-minute daily touchbases during peak (started one month before); enabled shift-by-shift responsiveness; achieved zero escalations, 93.3% average, zero PIPs during peak
Keith Deuber.context: Amazon's unique risk: 'Amazon is different from other accounts. This is not an account that is, you know, hey, you have a year contract, three-year contract, we'll review it at the end of the contract. This is truly you fail two months in a row, you could potentially be on a pip. We're fending off a pip. You fail three in a row, you could potentially be kicked out of the site. So the typical standard on SBM internal communications just didn't work because it's a week to week contract, almost a shift by shift. You could drop a ball on a shift, next you know you're getting escalations.' Solution: '(1) Utilizing teams and setting up individual region by region teams chats to ensure that we're communicating real time. (2) During peak, starting about a month before peak, we set up 15 minute touch bases every single day with the teams, with the site managers, the regional, the area managers, just to make sure that we're communicating who was on site, where are the challenges, where are the gaps, when's the audit, what are the challenges of that week or that day?' Peak results: 'That truly I think was a driver into having 0 escalations during peak averaging at 93.3, which is significantly higher than we averaged during the peak prior and we were the only company that had zero sites on PIP throughout Peak, which is what's called out through our supplier Peak debrief with Marco Rosano.' This demonstrates Keith's understanding that Amazon requires fundamentally different communication cadence than typical SBM accounts.
Keith Deuber.impact: Zero escalations during peak; 93.3% average (significantly higher than prior peak); only company with zero PIPs; real-time shift-level responsiveness
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Marco Rosano called out SBM as only company with zero PIPs during supplier peak debrief

Keith Deuber.title: BI Dashboard Proof of Concept - Predictive Site Failure Analysis
Keith Deuber.description: Created BI dashboard with innovations team to digest Amazon's weekly scorecard and KPI documents; enables predictive analysis of site failure trends; tracks week-over-week patterns; supports data-driven operational decisions
Keith Deuber.context: Challenge: 'Amazon provides us with the weekly scorecard and then we also have to implement and send in a KPI document detailing out hours utilization, any service credits, staffing and such like that. What we were struggling with at the beginning of the year was digesting and actioning on those items, finding the key indicators to a site or trending to a site that is failing or catching it before it starts to have an escalation.' Solution: 'We created a BI dashboard with the innovations team that really allows us internally to track and trend and make predictive analysis on where a site's trending. Is it going to fail? What are the week over week fail trends and really put it on to a dashboard that allows us to make data-driven decisions to be able to sustain high operations.' This demonstrates Keith's strategic thinking to move from reactive to predictive operations management.
Keith Deuber.impact: Predictive site failure analysis; proactive intervention before escalations; data-driven decisions; week-over-week trend identification
Keith Deuber.leadership_endorsement: Innovation team collaboration; moves from reactive to predictive operations

Tiffany Purifoy.title: Fidelity Scope Alignment - Off-Site Meeting Closed Financial Gap

Right now, if I'm not mistaken, our both locations are at full capacity, which makes it vital for us to have the conversation that we needed for comprehensive scope alignment.' We met off-site and we really need to align on expectations from carpet staining parameters to restroom cleaning frequencies. The discussion was really highly productive and did result in a mutual to agree upon contract which has already been signed and implemented this year and that's the scope expansion that closed the financial gap.' Valarie feedback on scope: 'Scope's been aligned. What could we have done differently?' - Tiffany's lesson: Should have done this earlier in transition, not leaned so heavily on transition team.

Tiffany Purifoy.title: Periodic Task Calendar - Eliminated Client Complaints at TRP Colorado
Tiffany Purifoy.description: Built calendar for TRP Colorado listing all periodic tasks and completion dates; sent to customer monthly with updates; reviewed in scorecard meetings; zero complaints since implementation; enhanced partnership through communication
Tiffany Purifoy.context: Problem: 'The lack of visibility to periodic tasks. This was a complaint, a consistent complaint in our Colorado location and the client was making us aware that they wanted to basically know when periodical tasks were completed so that they could then perform service validations.' Solution: 'What we did was build a calendar for the client listing all of the periodic tasks when they would be completed, and that calendar was sent to the customer with any necessary updates on a monthly basis and reviewed on our scorecard meetings.' Result: 'We've had zero complaints since we've implemented this new process and the client is very appreciative. Actually the partnership has grown stronger due to the enhanced communication.' Accountability: 'From an accountability standpoint, the periodical task should have been provided to our client ahead of time, not something that they should be asking or wondering if it was done. As an owner of the account, I should have ensured that (A) client asked for it twice and (B) ensure that these were plans and routes, some of them involved routes, were in place prior to the client requesting this information.'
Tiffany Purifoy.impact: Zero complaints since implementation; partnership strengthened through communication; client appreciative; proactive vs reactive approach established
Tiffany Purifoy.leadership_endorsement: Tiffany owns accountability - should have been proactive from start

Tiffany Purifoy.title: Mother's Room & Fitness Center Process - Prevented Repeat Privacy Incidents
Tiffany Purifoy.description: Implemented new entry process after two incidents at TRP (mother's room, fitness center); knock, wait 10 seconds, knock again, then enter even if IT light shows unoccupied; zero incidents since implementation; client appreciative
Tiffany Purifoy.context: Incidents: 'We've had two pretty important issues that occurred and one of them was an SBM entering a space. It was one of them was a mother's room. Another incident was a fitness center. Though I'm not sure if everyone's familiar with, there are lights on the door that let you know if it was occupied or not. In both incidences the IT stated that it was unoccupied. SBM employee knocked. There was no response. Employee entered to someone in the space.' Solution: 'Working directly with JLL and T. Rowe Price, we implemented a new process. That process basically states that employee is supposed to knock, wait a certain amount 10 seconds to enter, knock again and then enter the room because we obviously have keys to enter these spaces.' Result: 'Since this occurrence, both of those occurrences, there have been 0 incidences since implementation and the clients obviously really appreciate the implementation of this process.'
Tiffany Purifoy.impact: Zero privacy incidents since implementation; client appreciative; risk mitigated; process protects both occupants and SBM employees
Tiffany Purifoy.leadership_endorsement: Worked directly with JLL and TRP; client appreciative of process implementation

Greyson Wolff.title: Honda Portfolio Quality Turnaround - Q1 Struggles to Q2-Q4 Excellence
Greyson Wolff.description: Transformed Honda portfolio quality from 6 failed KPIs and 6 failed surveys in Q1 to only 3 failed KPIs and 1 failed survey in remaining 9 months; improved joint inspection scores from Q1 4.39 to Q2-Q4 4.54; achieved zero failed joint inspections all year
Greyson Wolff.context: Portfolio performance: '11 sites throughout 2025, we came through at a 4.94 performance score out of five for our scorecards. That's sitting at a 99 plus percent. Survey performance: '4.3 average score across the 133 surveys... seven surveys that were failed across the entirety of the year. Six of those came in Q1 and there was only one that came throughout the remaining nine months.' Inspection turnaround: 'Joint audits in Q1 came in at a 4.39 and our failed inspections of the 31 for the entire year, 24 of those failed inspections came in Q1... Strategic focus: 'Since we started the Honda portfolio and were awarded the growth that led us to the size of the business we have currently, from day one, we've been really focused on not only the existing business that we have, but making sure that we are posturing ourselves in a position to be prepared for the growth that exists in Ohio.' This demonstrates dramatic quality improvement and positioning for $1M growth opportunity (Ohio RFP Q4 2026).
Greyson Wolff.impact: Q1 → Q2-Q4: 6 failed KPIs → 3 failed KPIs; 6 failed surveys → 1 failed survey; 4.39 → 4.54 joint scores; zero failed joint inspections; positioned for Ohio growth
Greyson Wolff.leadership_endorsement: Valarie: 'You probably did the best of anyone presenting... You did the best of anyone presenting out of ForSight with your flow, your logic'

Greyson Wolff.title: Aztec Sidewinder Equipment - 50% Floor Stripping Time Reduction
Greyson Wolff.description: Introduced Aztec Sidewinder equipment for VCT floor stripping; piloted July 2025 in Georgia; reduced time/labor by 50%; delivered $5K December shutdown savings; forecasting $20K+ annual savings; reduced high-visibility area downtime for client
Greyson Wolff.context: Challenge: '100,000 square feet of VCT across nine different states is really no joke and so we've had to get creative in how we can figure out a way to support that.' Innovation: 'The Aztec Sidewinder is what we have introduced into the portfolio here at the end of December and something that's really going to be able to change the dynamic of how we are completing service within these shutdown periods. We ran a trial of this last July in Georgia. Love the results that we saw. And so from that we ordered 2 units, one to be used between Alabama and Georgia, another unit to be used in Indiana and Ohio.' Results: 'We quickly found that we can reduce the time that we are spending, the time and labor in stripping floors by about 50%. Internally what this allowed us to do just in one shutdown here in December of 2025 is provide about $5000 of cost savings for us internally, we're forecasting that at about $20,000 plus in 2026.' Client impact: 'These are very high visibility areas that we are having to shut down for days on end in order to be able to get through the work. Our opportunity to be able to do these quicker while still delivering just as high of a quality result, if not better and then be able to reallocate resources back throughout the plant to complete additional projects is something that is felt not only with our team internally, but really throughout the entirety of the facilities and the facilities team as well as the end users. We've been able to dramatically increase the amount of work that we're able to complete within a very jammed packed 8 to 10 day shutdown period.'
Greyson Wolff.impact: 50% time reduction; $5K December savings; $20K+ forecasted 2026 savings; reduced high-visibility area downtime; increased shutdown project capacity
Greyson Wolff.leadership_endorsement: Piloted before full investment; client impact on shutdown efficiency; increased work capacity

Greyson Wolff.title: Management Structure Investment - $18K Cost Avoidance to Honda
Greyson Wolff.description: Promoted Blake Pacheco to area manager (AAP/TMPG); hired William Smith as area manager (Hitachi Ostomo); brought on Christopher Blankenship (Ohio support); transformed from flat org chart to layered structure; $18K monthly cost avoidance to Honda while strengthening operations
Greyson Wolff.context: Starting point: 'At the beginning of 2025 when we started the year both from the HDMA portfolio and the American Honda, every single one of these sites were flat across our org chart. Then we had the growth with Hitachi Ostomo, which allowed us to bring on another area manager in William Smith, give Blake the opportunity to be promoted into a role to oversee those existing locations as well as additional locations on our American Honda side of things. And then as we closed out the year here in transition into 2026, Christopher Blankenship has been brought on board of our team in the Ohio market to help support some of the locations that don't have dedicated site management.' Financial impact: 'We have two positions in our area manager and our senior area manager, Blake Pacheco and William Smith. The investment that we are pouring back into the portfolio there is $18,000 in cost avoidance on the Honda side of things.' Customer communication: 'One of the biggest things that we've been able to share through scorecard reviews, through formal business reviews is really the commitment that we have to the relationship with Honda and ultimately how that has translated to quality delivery. That starts with the investment that we have made to our management team.'

This demonstrates ability to make strategic investments that support quality delivery and position for growth.

Siddarth Shah.title: Curbit Award - Sustainability & Recycling Leadership Recognition
Siddarth Shah.description: SBM team in Boise awarded the Curbit Award by City and County of Boise for exceptional recycling and sustainability efforts; team serves as frontline of Micron's sustainability program across 5.3M sq ft facility with 175 restrooms
Siddarth Shah.context: Recognition: 'One of the major initiatives that we wanted to highlight were our sustainability efforts. Our team supports the sustainability and the recycling efforts in Boise. With our team being the front line of the recycling and the sustainability section of Micron in Boise, we actually got awarded the Curbit award by the city and county of Boise, which was a huge win, and our team played a huge role supporting those efforts.' Scale: 5.3M sq ft campus, 175 restroom sets, 201 employees. 2026 initiatives: 'Scrape the Plate program initiative piloted in San Jose, sourcing new compostable liners, new trash/recycling/compost waste management program in San Jose and Boise, presenting cost savings to the client.'
Siddarth Shah.impact: City/county recognition for environmental leadership; positions SBM as sustainability partner; piloting new programs across portfolio (Scrape the Plate, compostable liners, comprehensive waste management)
Siddarth Shah.leadership_endorsement: External recognition from city/county; client partnership on sustainability

Siddarth Shah.title: Paper Products Repurposing - Indirect Cost Savings & Carbon Footprint Reduction
Siddarth Shah.description: Instead of disposing paper products at 15% remaining, repurposing them for spills, leaks, and wipe-downs; reduces laundry costs, electricity usage, water consumption, and carbon footprint from rag washing
Siddarth Shah.context: Scale context: 'Having a site like Boise which stretches 5.3 million square feet, 175 sets of restrooms, the amount of toilet roll that gets used on a daily basis and the amount of waste of paper products was astronomical.' Innovation: 'We started repurposing our paper products. Any paper products that reach 15% need to be changed out and replenished, but we were not disposing those. We are now using, we are repurposing those for spills, any kind of leaks and any wipe downs that we need to do around the facility.' Impact: 'Might not seem like much, but this actually saves us doing laundry with our rags. It saves us with electricity. It actually reduces our carbon footprint. So there's a lot of cost savings indirectly. It's not necessarily monetary cost savings, but how are we using these products until we can actually dispose them without having impacts on using additional water and additional chemical going into our washing of the rags.' Client collaboration: 'We put together some information, data and presented it to the client. We made recommendations like maybe we should start using more bamboo based products, recycling products.'
Siddarth Shah.impact: Indirect cost savings across laundry/electricity/water; reduced carbon footprint; extended product lifecycle; data-driven sustainability presentation to client
Siddarth Shah.leadership_endorsement: Client approved after data presentation; sustainability alignment with Micron values

Siddarth Shah.title: Window Washing Vendor Optimization - $15K Cost Reduction + Revenue Increase
Siddarth Shah.description: Reduced exterior window washing costs in San Jose by $15K through competitive vendor bidding, then proposed twice-yearly service (vs once yearly), converting cost savings into revenue growth opportunity
Siddarth Shah.context: Process: 'We worked with our management team, especially on the window washing projects and our pressure washing projects that we subcontract. We actually worked with different vendors and we had different vendors come out to the site and we reduced the cost of the window washing services by approximately $15,000.' Strategic conversion: 'Now of course that is considered ATB (above the bid), but the proposal was instead of doing the window washing once a year, we'll do it twice a year and that was approved by San Jose. So we're actually making a little bit more money when it comes to the subcontracting of the window washing, but that was a $15,000 cost savings for San Jose.' Impact: 'That was a huge win for us.'
Siddarth Shah.impact: $15K annual cost reduction for client; increased service frequency from 1x to 2x yearly; improved subcontract margins; strengthened client partnership
Siddarth Shah.leadership_endorsement: Client approved increased service frequency at reduced annual cost

Siddarth Shah.title: Waxy Urine Digester Innovation - Eliminates Urinal Mats & Restroom Closures
Siddarth Shah.description: Introduced Waxy urine digester/remover product in Boise that eliminates need for urinal mats, can be used during all shifts without closing restrooms, more effective than previous Citro Stride product, environmentally friendly
Siddarth Shah.context: Product benefits: 'Nothing special, but the nice thing about this product, it eliminates the use of urinal mats. So the customer doesn't need to buy urinal mats no more. It can be used during all shifts and we will not need to close down restrooms during the day. That basically means it increases productivity. We do not need to close down restrooms in order to start mopping underneath urinals and any restrooms as a whole.' Performance: 'It's tested and proven to be more effective than the current product that we were using called Citro Stride. Jacob Reed.title: Proactive Maintenance Approach - $6K Sink to $120 Fixture Root Cause Analysis

Jacob Reed.context: Reactive past: 'For the longest time we've been really reactive and we kind of just taking things and kind of like how do we get to the next ticket. I think Edgar and his team are really taking that to be more of a proactive approach instead of just throwing, allowing us to throw money at it and just say the sink is broken, just buy a new one. It costs like $6,000 for the sink.' Proactive approach: 'Edgar and his team actually took a second to say, hey, what do we find on the root of the problem? They remove the sink and find out there's just calcium buildup or inadequate pieces that people just kind of threw together because there was a deadline to get these areas turn over. Now we're actually bringing these permanent solutions that are actually instead of a $6,000 sink, it's replacing $120 fixture.' Client response: 'Now we're really getting our foothold on there where it's even getting to the part where they're like, hey, can you guys partner with facilities? What does it look like to give SBM more of the visual, more of the eye-opening to the maintenance world that goes into keeping the factory up and running.' Impact: 'It really just helps elevate us to where we're walking step with Tesla where it's how do we keep SBM growing with us.'
Jacob Reed.impact: Massive cost savings via root cause analysis ($120 vs $6K example); Tesla requesting facilities partnership expansion; elevated from 'vendor to the side' to strategic partner; Edgar leadership recognized

Jacob Reed.context: Challenge: 'Tesla kind of exploded and revitalized their program. A lot of shops opened up for us and really was tasked with like how quickly can SBM scale this. Tesla likes to tell themselves they want to be first to everything. They want things done in such a rapid pace that you don't really have time to catch your breath. The opening of the Cyber Cab station, the envelopment of the new Model Y and the battery expansion pieces all deemed a pretty heavy need for additional scope and additional headcount.' Execution: 'We were able to knock that out of the park with most lead time, about two weeks to get employees into the door and then see them up and running. One of the only vendors that could really meet those demands.' Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: Competitive differentiator for Tesla relationship; HR/recruiting/operations collaboration model

Jacob Reed.title: Flood Support Process - $200K Savings + 4 Hours to 45 Minutes Response
Jacob Reed.description: Developed systematic flood response process reducing response time from 4 hours to 45 minutes; saved Tesla $200K in 2025 by eliminating need for subcontractors; tracking and quantifying value monthly
Jacob Reed.context: Problem: 'With the amount of adjustments and demand that Tesla's doing of like moving the factory around daily, monthly, there's always someone that's hitting either a pipe or hitting fire sprinklers, releasing hundreds of thousands of gallons of water. It became just an ordeal where production is down. Everybody's just waiting. The cars won't move because there's water in the way.' Old process: 'In the past it's taken us about four hours to get all this water kind of in once to center, get it all taken care of, get it all soaked up and moved on.' New process: 'Now where it's down to like 45 minutes to an hour, hour at the max. There's a process, there's a direction and there's guidance from our team. Our team looks like they're supposed to be there. People get excited where they're like SBM's here, they're going to take care of this water. We can keep moving from production because everybody's getting hounded in the background of like, why aren't these cars being made?' Value quantification: 'We were happy to announce to them that we saved them about $200K in savings. It wasn't necessarily built into our scope when we first started. We were just there for more of a residual water cleanup to where we took on the actual flooding in itself. They're not having to bring out any subvendors.' Tracking: 'We're able to give them that like a solid number. Now we're tracking that daily, monthly for them to be able to see that we are bringing that value add.'
Jacob Reed.impact: $200K annual savings quantified; 75% time reduction (4 hours → 45 min); eliminated subcontractor delays (4-24 hour wait); production uptime protected; sticky service enhancement
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: John Mann requested documentation for scaling; Valarie emphasized huge win

Jacob Reed.title: Cost Savings Strategy Shift - Budget Alignment vs Egregious Demands
Jacob Reed.description: Shifted narrative from client-demanded cost savings ($600K+/month expectations) to proactive budget alignment with factory schedules; delivered $250K in holiday/shutdown savings while protecting operational integrity
Jacob Reed.context: Old approach problem: 'The real goal internally for me is getting away from planning Tesla a lot of these cost savings. When we first started the account it was like how can we get SBM to give us more than $600,000 a month back in cost savings? It was like an expectation for you guys to just give us a giant amount of money back. It became like a nightmare trying to move things around.' New approach: 'I really wanted to show them the overall leader budget, being able to tell them these are necessities that we need. We're not over asking. We're not trying to take advantage. It was more or less aligning with them. We'll give you the cost savings that structure with how the factory operates, IE like holidays and factory shutdowns. We're able to go in there, produce some savings for them and say like, you guys are down, we see that we're not going to overstaff for a factory that's dead.' Results: 'Aligning with them on their schedules, kind of integrating into what Tesla's doing and kind of getting ahead of it instead of asking the customer how much do you need to save. It's more or less like, hey, what does the schedule looks like? Oh great, with that kind of reductions I can save you guys as much money. That one also came out to about $250K with the reduction there. Those were like just for major holidays, Christmas, Thanksgiving, 4th of July, MLK Day and Veteran's Day.' Philosophy: 'It's a really good way to just not allow them to push us around and kind of put our foot down and say, hey, we're going to move in the right direction of the budgets that we asked for are lean because they reflect exactly what we need and any kind of cost savings we'll be more than happy to give back to you, but those are justified and not like being over budgeted.'
Jacob Reed.impact: $250K holiday/shutdown savings delivered; eliminated $600K+ egregious demands; established budget integrity; proactive scheduling alignment; protected operational necessities
Jacob Reed.leadership_endorsement: Shifted power dynamic; sustainable cost savings model vs unsustainable demands

You own the scope gaps, you own whatever we negotiated. You're stuck with it. In order to build the best client relationship going in right off of a transition, the first thing I would do is sit down align. Do we 100% agree on scope? Do we agree on frequency? Do we agree on quote unquote the contract headcount? Do we agree on how we're scoring ourselves? Do we agree on taking surveys, walking together? All that stuff is supposed to be the baseline of what happens.' Tiffany: 'If we were aligned on those things from the beginning, I think the moment of I don't want to say tension, but not being in alignment would have dissipated sooner, which would have impacted maybe higher I perform score scoring from Q2 and maybe not taken. While you see a gradual move here from Q2 to Q3, you'll see 2.55 to 2.97 to 3.34. My decision making and adjustments need to occur faster.' Tiffany (on what stopped her): 'In the beginning, well one giving grace for the transition... after that I leaned too heavily on our transition team in the routes and any adjustments that needed to be made when I needed to say no, this isn't working, this is the avenue that we need to take.'

Tiffany Purifoy.title: Resolve CSAT Scoring Discrepancy - Align CBRE to ForSight or Change Approach
Tiffany Purifoy.quote: Tiffany: 'Holding myself and my team responsible, including all of the four insight management. So what we've done is create a live sheet, a live Excel sheet that we're all sharing and I have recruiting updating in real time so that I don't have to, when I decide to work on a weekend, bug anyone to understand and get the most updated information. Some of the processes that we have are so antiquated when we have tools that will allow us to work smarter.'
Tiffany Purifoy.action: 2026 Process Review: (1) Identify 'hamster wheel' processes that rinse and repeat without improvement, (2) Hiring process improvement: Live Excel sheet for recruiting updates (already implemented) - replicate this thinking elsewhere, (3) Eliminate email chasing: use real-time shared documents, (4) Leverage available tools: 'We have tools that will allow us to work smarter' - what else is being underutilized?, (5) Hold people accountable to new processes: adoption is key, (6) Areas to evaluate: onboarding, equipment tracking, CSAT follow-up, periodic task management, client communication, (7) Goal: Make smarter decisions faster with better information flow

Request an MIT? How are you going to train that part? I want to give you full credit.'
Corey Wallace.action: Send SMART goals to attendees within a day. Include: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound. For operations role: steps to reach out to HR, request MIT, training plan. By end of Q1/Q2—what steps? Upload to Workday.

So it's not just a conversation that comes up with the upcoming RFPs and so forth that we have. So we're using every touch point as a marketing communications opportunity to deliver messages like you did today.'

I think that is really a strength of yours, just assimilating the learnings from others.'

Siddarth Shah.title: 8 FTEs White Glove Service - $37K/Month Executive Building Restroom Enhancement Submitted
Siddarth Shah.quote: Siddarth: 'We've submitted proposals for an additional 8 FTEs to enhance the white glove services in executive buildings and executive spaces specifically for restrooms that should be bringing in at least $37,000 a month.'
Siddarth Shah.action: $37K/mo proposal submitted for 8 FTEs (executive restrooms). Set CNW decision date; if approved, define staffing and implementation timeline. Addresses San Jose white-glove expectations.

Colleen Doles.category: Key Projects - Client Outcomes vs Activity
Colleen Doles.title: Key Projects = What Did We Do That Mattered to the Client?
Colleen Doles.quote: Valarie: 'The key projects and initiatives is really about what did we do that mattered to the client? Were there anything that changed for the client as a result? So if we gave 16% as a cost savings, but we haven't changed any scope of work or we haven't worked with the client on the side of like still delivering excellence at that 16% savings - that at some point is probably going to come around to bite us because they're getting the same service level with a reduction of costs. So how are we going to... Is the client aware that we've saved them 16% or only JLL knows?'
Colleen Doles.action: 2026: (1) Ensure Wells Fargo (not just JLL) understands 16% savings, (2) Document client-facing outcomes from 2025 - what changed for them?, (3) If presenting to Wells Fargo + JLL: Las Colinas, beyond-scope work (partition holes, toilet dispensers), contract-freeze partnership; (4) Scope reductions to align with 16% - client awareness of headcount reductions

Colleen Doles.category: Value Adds - Quantify with Dollar Figures
Colleen Doles.title: Quantify Value Adds - Reduces Point Value If You Can't
Colleen Doles.quote: Valarie: 'Do you have a dollar figure to these numbers or these things that you have on here? It reduces your point value if you can't quantify it... What is the delta between what Canteen would charge and what we charge?' Colleen: 'I unfortunately don't have that information - they sourced quotes from them privately and then awarded the work to us.'
Colleen Doles.action: 2026: (1) Canteen support - get delta from Canteen quote if possible; document ~$5K/mo (Las Colinas $2K, San Antonio $2K, Minneapolis ~$1K), (2) Added locations - Santa Barbara ~$4,500/mo; total incremental revenue; (3) Value add = service we could have charged for but didn't - track gratuitous items with dollar figures

Colleen Doles.category: Service Validation - Full Upload with Photos, Not Just QR Scan
Colleen Doles.title: Use Latest Service Validation - Photos + AI Scoring, Not Just QR Scan
Colleen Doles.quote: Valarie: 'If I was going to pilot service validation somewhere over the last year, that's the only kind of pilot I would do because the other one doesn't... it's not really innovative. The full AI model where the cleaners are doing the work and taking the photo and then it's scoring and scaling - that is what they're moving towards. In your next round where you are having problems, I highly recommend you only use the latest and greatest version because that's the one where it proves that you did the work, not just that you were there.'
Colleen Doles.action: 2026: (1) Easttown pilot - QR scan only; prove staff can do scans; (2) Arizona - use full version with photo upload + AI scoring when rolled out; (3) Quantify: does service validation drive behavior, increase audit scores? Run technical pilot with before/after data

Colleen Doles.title: Upon Award: Contract Discussion Meeting to Realign Expectations
Colleen Doles.quote: Valarie: 'When we transition a new site, we would sit down with our POC through baselines, reset, get to the level of understanding. Did we have a top-to-top overview of the contract, reset expectations even for ourselves, reset our scoring criteria and do all of that with them? If we did, when did we do that?' Colleen: 'We have not done that yet. I view that as part of the KPI agreement and alignment through this RFP process.' Valarie: 'Upon award - meeting to be set. I don't think the contract can be signed until that happens.'
Colleen Doles.action: Upon RFP award: (1) Schedule contract discussion meeting with JLL/Wells Fargo, (2) Reset baselines, scoring criteria, expectations, (3) Top-to-top overview - old scope vs new scope, (4) JLL took over Nov 1 - 4 months of misalignment; Tripp understands; others don't

Colleen Doles.title: Goals: Specific, Measurable, Time-Bound - Don't Include What You Can't Control
Colleen Doles.quote: Valarie: 'A goal written down without a date on it is a wish. Charlotte - you have no control over that. So that can't be a goal of yours if they award Charlotte or they don't... I would never want to hold you accountable for something that in all reality you don't have an influence over. Charlotte - that bread is in the oven already. So what are the steps that you're going to take in order to grow to those locations? Yeah, that'd be great. That'd be cool. Best practice. Thanks.'

Who deploys? Who coordinates with Tesla production?, Response time benchmarks (45 min - 1 hour max), Training requirements for team members, Safety protocols, Communication process with Tesla during flood events, (3) VALUE PROPOSITION TO DOCUMENT: Time reduction: 4 hours → 45 minutes (75% improvement), Cost savings: $200K annually by eliminating subcontractors, Production uptime protection, Professional appearance ('Team looks like they're supposed to be there'), (4) SCALABILITY GOAL: John Mann identified this as scalable across other SBM locations, Other sites may have similar needs (manufacturing, data centers with water risks), Best practice for SBM enterprise-wide, (5) TIMELINE: Set completion date for documentation, Set review date with John Mann and tech team, Set date for presenting to other ADs/sites as best practice, (6) STRATEGIC IMPORTANCE: Differentiates SBM as emergency response capable, Quantifiable value add ($200K), Trackable metrics (time, cost), Replicable process for portfolio growth

Jacob Reed.title: Set Realistic Timeline for Being First SBM Vendor to Implement Optimus
Jacob Reed.quote: Jacob: 'My kind of goal here and I need you to kind of be patient with me is I want to be the first vendor to implement Optimus into one of our programs, one of our routes. I want to be the one that gets ahead of it with Tesla early to say like hey, let us be kind of the Guinea pig with getting this Optimus robot to either clean floors, clean the bathroom, service something, pick up trash, do something. I think it does a really good job of saying like, hey, we're willing to jump to those risky avenues with you. I think it too, it also helps shift like, hey, let us set up the narrative of this is what Optimus can do at the maximum instead of the latter where Tesla tells us, hey, we're gonna give you guys 5 robots, we need you to incorporate it, but we also need to cut 30% of your headcount. So I think it really does a really good job of allowing us to kind of tell them what we think Optimus to do instead of them telling us what we need to do with it. That's something I want to get to and have those conversations with you guys, but obviously I'll give you some time to chew on that. It's not like I'm going to do it tomorrow. I just want to be able to kind of let them know in the conversation like, yeah, I think it's really, really awesome to be in there with what Tesla's moving to.'
Jacob Reed.action: Optimus implementation strategic planning: (1) JACOB'S VISION: Be FIRST SBM vendor to implement Optimus robot, Pilot one route or task: floors, bathrooms, trash pickup, 'Guinea pig' approach - willing to test risky avenues, STRATEGIC GOAL: Control the narrative of what Optimus CAN do (maximize capabilities), vs Tesla dictating what Optimus MUST do (replace 30% headcount), Proactive vs reactive positioning, (2) VAL'S FEEDBACK ON TIMELINE: 'A goal without a date is just a wish', 'If you say I want Optimus to be at one of the Tesla sites, we would need to know the release date of Optimus and then work backwards for implementation, purchase and implementation and start to come up with the actual strategy around that', Need concrete timeline, not aspirational 'I want to', (3) REQUIRED RESEARCH/PLANNING: Optimus release date: When is it commercially available for pilot?, Optimus capabilities: What CAN it realistically do in 2026? (floors, bathrooms, trash - is this feasible?), Cost: Purchase vs lease? Budget approval needed?, Training: What's required to operate/maintain Optimus?, Integration: How does it work with existing routes/team?, Success metrics: How will pilot be evaluated?, (4) CONVERSATIONS WITH LEADERSHIP: Jacob: 'I want to have those conversations with you guys', Set date for Optimus strategy discussion with Nick, Valarie, Nicole, Set date for Tesla conversation about piloting (after internal approval), Get leadership buy-in before proposing to Tesla, (5) RISKS TO ADDRESS: Jacob's concern: 'Tesla tells us give you guys 5 robots, we need you to incorporate it, but we also need to cut 30% of your headcount', How to position pilot to avoid headcount reduction mandate?, What's the ROI that protects jobs vs eliminates them?, Is Optimus pilot genuinely helpful or just following Tesla's vision without SBM benefit?, (6) TIMELINE PRESSURE: Jacob: 'It's not like I'm going to do it tomorrow', But also: 'I want to be the FIRST vendor', Need to balance patience/realism with first-mover advantage, Other vendors may be having same conversations with Tesla, Set specific milestones: Q1 research, Q2 leadership approval, Q3 Tesla proposal, Q4 pilot?, (7) VAL'S OVERALL MESSAGE: 'I want to help you get there. But the only way that I can do that is for you to put dates. I want you to develop this out. Everything needs a date.'

Dustin Smith.title: Management Process Enhancement - Bring Site Managers to SBM Standard
Dustin Smith.quote: Management process enhancement and standardization. Like I said previously, we took on a lot of incumbent managers, external hires, nobody with a lot of SBM stink on them. This is really doing a deep dive training and making sure that we're bringing our site managers up to the SBM standard as quickly as possible. This is an ongoing effort. Greyson Wolff.title: Escalate to Plant Manager After False Accusations (TMPG Incidents)

After some investigation, after being able to provide some evidence, it was made abundantly clear that SBM was nowhere in the vicinity nor at fault of these issues. However, sometimes when that connotation gets out in the air, it's a little bit more difficult to kick the last one.' Learning: 'Where the opportunity existed is after that first incident took place that was found to not be at SBM's fault. That's when we should have had the opportunity to sit down with that plant management team and be able to make it abundantly clear that that's how the situation unfolded... I think it just really comes back to communication with the folks that are in charge and really making the decisions at those plant levels.' Valarie: 'What would you have done differently?' Greyson: 'We had made the request with our site level POC to have that audience. It kind of fell against deaf ears and I think for me that's where I have the opportunity to meet with my regional POC and I'm pretty confident we would have had the chance to do that. And so I think that's where I let it slide when I shouldn't have.' Valarie: 'So you would have advocated harder to get the meeting.'
Greyson Wolff.action: Future protocol: (1) After false safety accusation is proven wrong, escalate immediately to plant manager level, (2) Don't accept 'fell against deaf ears' from site POC - go to regional POC, (3) Clear air proactively vs waiting for perception to linger, (4) Third incident: SBM employee was at fault, terminated appropriately, (5) WIN: Got closed-door meeting with plant manager and department leads post-incident - showcased ForSight, quality processes, safety standards, (6) Lesson: Should have had that meeting after FIRST false accusation, not after third incident, (7) Communication with decision-makers is key - don't let site-level communication gaps fester

Keith Deuber.title: Equipment Gap - Wrong Equipment Choice (Scrubbers vs Sweepers)
