As we're moving through Amazon, as we're maturing within Amazon, we're learning more and more what we need is staffing equipment. What we're dealing with with the current sites is the right on equipment. I think that's the biggest challenge we have being that with the amount of dust, cardboard debris, you know, anything you can think of from a warehouse perspective, we really need sweepers. Sweeper scrubbers or sweepers and when we went into this originally we focused on scrubbers. Scrubbers don't necessarily pick up debris which it gets clocked up. It gets there's a lot of issues when it comes to downtime with scrubbers in a warehouse setting. And so it's truly causing a challenge when it comes to operation and we saw it during peak big time.
Keith Deuber.action: Q1-Q2 2026: (1) Work with procurement on existing sites + idle asset list, (2) Bill Darlington assessing equipment at warehouse, (3) Swap out scrubbers for sweepers at current sites, (4) Create equipment list for upcoming sites - 'Know which ones we need for which site types,' (5) Ready to order correct equipment when capturing new sites, (6) Lessons learned: warehouse = debris/dust = sweepers; offices = floors = scrubbers, (7) Peak proactive response: had 10+ equipment rental agencies ready, got equipment same/next day - maintain this contingency approach

Jennifer Segovia.title: Strategic Plan for Over-Capacity (Minivan Analogy)
Jennifer Segovia.quote: Valarie: 'If we all get in the minivan and drive to LA, there's going to be more trash, more waste... As you get to capacities in excess of 100% of capacity, our work schedules, routes and all of that are not built to sustain. Complaints will go up, carpet spills will increase, trash will double. You have to be cognizant of that and I'd like you to come up with a strategic plan for over-capacity... Reach out to John, ask him who you can work with on his team [Microsoft] that's really good at that.'
Jennifer Segovia.action: 2026: (1) Chandler 500 people crammed into 3rd floor - strategic plan for capacity load, (2) Scottsdale Roosevelt - same dynamic; (3) Contact Microsoft team (John) for capacity load best practices, (4) Propose something back to customer in accordance to capacity

Jennifer Segovia.title: Flush Out Safety Culture Strategy with Milestones and Actions
Jennifer Segovia.quote: Valarie: 'Maintaining safety culture. I understand those as a general KPI and requirement. What I don't understand is your strategic plan or timeline for that. So like yes, you want to strengthen operational safety excellence, but how will you do it? And what are your milestones? What's driving that safety culture? What can we do differently? Are we also celebrating that with a client? Joint safety trainings in person if applicable or via phone - when and where? How often are those trainings? How many are you committed to a year?'
Jennifer Segovia.action: Document: (1) Safety culture milestones and timeline, (2) Joint Northrop/GD safety trainings - when, where, how many/year, (3) What drives safety culture (awards, parties, etc.), (4) Steps to get to 0 recordables

Jennifer Segovia.category: Northrop Grumman RFP - Influencers & Decision Makers
Jennifer Segovia.title: Map Key Influencers, Decision Makers, and RFP Timeline
Jennifer Segovia.quote: Nick: 'This is one of our biggest opportunities of the year. Ton of eyeballs on it... Who are the key influencers? Who are the decision makers? What meetings are we having? What exposure are we getting to those folks early and often in preparation to a June RFP? The monthly, quarterly business reviews all mean way more than they ever have before. Enterprise selling is a team sport. How do we parlay the excellent work you and your teams are doing into telling that story to the right influencers and decision makers? Getting those meetings locked in, timelines aligned... We can work back and help you build out the content, the decks, present, setting up Melissa for dinners and meetings with the right stakeholders.'
Jennifer Segovia.action: With Melissa: (1) Map key influencers and decision makers (California/Servicon accounts drive RFP; Gilbert reports to CA), (2) Chris (Northrop Gilbert) - meeting next week for CA facilities head name, (3) Smart objectives: influencers, key moments, content, (4) Jeff: 50% Northrop buy-in - target non-bought-in, (5) Jen: 'Do whatever it takes' - cost flexibility to get foot in door

Jennifer Segovia.title: Develop Jose (#2) with Specific Steps - Three Main + Stretch
Jennifer Segovia.quote: Valarie: 'What are some of the steps that you could take in order to develop them? Flush things out a little more. Maybe give yourself three main ones and a stretch one... Where has Jose gone to help out on a transition? Have you sent him somewhere where he can go out and develop and learn? Have you developed relationships with the sourcing manager at General Dynamics - when is your next meeting with that person? When are you taking them to dinner, lunch, coffee, breakfast? Just to get to know that person, not to talk about work.'
Jennifer Segovia.action: Jose development: (1) Send to transition/site for hands-on development, (2) Time management coaching - 'when too many things, I see things drop', (3) Three main goals + stretch; (4) GD sourcing: next meeting, dinner/lunch/coffee with Ethan contacts

Jennifer Segovia.title: Hold to Delegation Goal - Don't Own Everything
Jennifer Segovia.quote: Valarie: 'You don't have to be the strongest one in the room. You don't have to put the whole company on your back. You do have to be able to delegate... When you're in a one parent home, there's a level of guilt. You feel like you have to be everything to everybody, but ultimately you have to be the best to yourself so that you have something to give to them. Don't ever forget to put yourself first.'
Jennifer Segovia.action: Valarie will hold to delegation goal; 'Let Them' book - balance with kids (father passed); put self first; delegate vs owning everything

Gregory DeMedio.title: Add Specific Dates and Actions to All 2026 Goals
Gregory DeMedio.quote: A goal without a date is just a wish. I see a lot of things that are strategy and ideation. I really would like to see what actions are you going to take and by when so that when you meet with Dan or Marvin you can say I'm holding myself accountable.
Gregory DeMedio.action: Convert all 2026 strategy items into actionable goals with completion dates: (1) Latam key contact meeting - by Q1, (2) High-value QBR revamp - specific date, (3) Succession plan - timeline, (4) All sites periodical calendars - Q2 end, (5) Growth opportunities (Westford, St. Paul) - decision by Feb; track in monthly leadership meetings

Gregory DeMedio.title: Develop Client-Facing Projects and Initiatives with Measurable Impact
Gregory DeMedio.quote: These are important for us, but I see those as a part of your job. I don't see where at a particular site you had scope impact. What did we do for Abbott last year? I felt like you kind of pulled out some straws in order to fill something up on the page.
Gregory DeMedio.action: 2026 goal: identify and execute client-facing initiatives that deliver measurable value Abbott would recognize (not just internal operational improvements); focus on results over activities; differentiate between job expectations and value creation; track impact metrics

Gregory DeMedio.title: Improve Storytelling with Impact, Dates, and Actions
Gregory DeMedio.quote: In 2026, maybe working on your storytelling. I felt like some of the gaps were the impact, the dates, no actions. I think that also help you with your time management.
Gregory DeMedio.action: Develop narrative structure for future presentations that clearly articulates: (1) What was done (activity), (2) Why it mattered (impact), (3) When it was completed (dates), (4) What client value was created (results); practice storytelling to convey complexity and effort effectively

Gregory DeMedio.title: Track Accomplishments Throughout Year to 'Brag Better'
Gregory DeMedio.quote: Get better with tracking some of these things. Even Tony said about just tracking and sharing information. You do great things, but when you look back 12 months ago, it's like 'I don't know what I did.' You need to brag on yourself a little.
Gregory DeMedio.action: Implement quarterly or monthly accomplishment tracking system; document client wins, operational improvements, cost savings, relationship milestones as they happen; share with Tony regularly; maintain for year-end review to demonstrate full scope of work and value delivered

Gregory DeMedio.title: Revamp QBR to Be High-Value and Expand Audience
Gregory DeMedio.quote: QBR is very stale, just going over data. I do that with Tony almost every week, so it's redundant. Trying to come up with fresh ideas: voice of customer, site spotlights, driving more into value of SBM.
Gregory DeMedio.action: Redesign QBR format to: (1) Highlight SBM GMP capabilities and regulatory audit success, (2) Add site spotlights showcasing specific value, (3) Include voice of customer feedback, (4) Invite site-level executives or broader Abbott audiences, (5) Differentiate SBM vs competitors (what can't ABM do?); work with Tony to expand attendee list

Gregory DeMedio.title: Strengthen Relationships Beyond Tony Garcia to Key Stakeholders
Gregory DeMedio.quote: I have a great relationship with Tony, but where's that Latin America key contact or site-level senior executives? Bringing them more to the fold so they can understand the value we bring.
Gregory DeMedio.action: Identify and engage: (1) Latam key decision maker, (2) Site-level senior executives (met a few, expand relationships), (3) Abbott corporate stakeholders beyond procurement; loop them into portfolio conversations, year-end reviews, and value demonstrations

Gregory DeMedio.title: Improve Time Management by Delegating and Empowering Managers
Gregory DeMedio.quote: I need to get better with time management, prioritizing, delegating and empowering managers. I get more into the weeds than I probably should instead of delegating. It's my nature, but I need to focus on higher-end things.
Gregory DeMedio.action: Shift from 'in the weeds' to strategic focus: delegate operational tasks to site/area managers; continue weekly training programs for newer managers but empower them to execute; prioritize high-impact activities (senior relationships, growth, innovation); develop succession plan (already in discussion)

Gregory DeMedio.title: Better Articulate Account Complexity in Presentations
Gregory DeMedio.quote: There is an opportunity for folks on this call to understand the amount of complexity on your account - 26 sites, unique things you have to do. The efforts and how hard you work didn't come across. Complexities should be mentioned in presentations.
Gregory DeMedio.action: In future presentations, explicitly communicate: (1) Managing 26 different site relationships, (2) Annual site-specific contract renewals, (3) Regional/divisional team coordination complexity, (4) Unique Abbott requirements (no formal RFPs, strategic growth only); tell the story of effort and complexity to demonstrate scope of work
